repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
May not be the perfect and definitive fix, but hopefully better than adding workarounds with `#pragma GCC ...`.

Fixes #2747.

comment_data.body: I just wonder if something to test this should be included in the test? It isn't obvious to me whether this should be inside an `else` or not.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2517,8 +2517,11 @@ def declare_cfunction(self, name, type, pos,
                 if entry.is_final_cmethod and entry.is_inherited:
                     error(pos, "Overriding final methods is not allowed")
                 elif type.same_c_signature_as(entry.type, as_cmethod = 1) and type.nogil == entry.type.nogil:
-                    # Fix with_gil vs nogil.
-                    entry.type = entry.type.with_with_gil(type.with_gil)
+                    if self.parent_type.is_final_type:
+                        entry = self.add_cfunction(name, type, pos, cname, visibility='ignore', modifiers=modifiers)
+                    else:
+                        # Fix with_gil vs nogil.
+                        entry.type = entry.type.with_with_gil(type.with_gil)

comment_data.body:
This whole thing confuses me as well. I have not idea what to exactly test for. I just assumed that if a new final method is being added to a scopy, the input type information and its gil properties are already properly set, therefore you just create a new entry. 

The else branch is just leaving things as they were before, without messing with them in any way. I'm just trying to fix the underlying issue the right way, not with a low-quality temporary workaround as before, while minimizing the risk of breaking something. It looks really weird that this else branch would mess in such a way with `entry.type` in for an already-declared entry that comes from the parent type scope. But I'm admittedly not an expert, therefore I'm not going to mess with what was already there.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2517,8 +2517,11 @@ def declare_cfunction(self, name, type, pos,
                 if entry.is_final_cmethod and entry.is_inherited:
                     error(pos, "Overriding final methods is not allowed")
                 elif type.same_c_signature_as(entry.type, as_cmethod = 1) and type.nogil == entry.type.nogil:
-                    # Fix with_gil vs nogil.
-                    entry.type = entry.type.with_with_gil(type.with_gil)
+                    if self.parent_type.is_final_type:
+                        entry = self.add_cfunction(name, type, pos, cname, visibility='ignore', modifiers=modifiers)
+                    else:
+                        # Fix with_gil vs nogil.
+                        entry.type = entry.type.with_with_gil(type.with_gil)

comment_data.body: I'm a little suspicious of excluding fused types, but I think there are probably other issues with fused methods (https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5931) so maybe we should worry too much right now and sort it out later
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2551,6 +2551,9 @@ def declare_cfunction(self, name, type, pos,
         if self.parent_type.is_final_type or entry.is_inline_cmethod or self.directives.get('final'):
             entry.is_final_cmethod = True
             entry.final_func_cname = entry.func_cname
+            if not type.is_fused:

comment_data.body:
I had to exclude them here because otherwise at C code generation time, the fused type is asked for the C signature, which leads to a explicit compiler failure. 
I believe addressing fused methods in full should be for another rodeo, indeed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2551,6 +2551,9 @@ def declare_cfunction(self, name, type, pos,
         if self.parent_type.is_final_type or entry.is_inline_cmethod or self.directives.get('final'):
             entry.is_final_cmethod = True
             entry.final_func_cname = entry.func_cname
+            if not type.is_fused:

comment_data.body: What we usually do instead of a `getattr()` is to add the new attribute normally as a class (default) attribute in `Entry` and then set it only when we have something reasonable to assign it to. That way, it always exists.

commit.message: Fix self cast when calling final methods

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Fix bad self casts when calling methods of final types
